segments.text: This is occurring between 36 and 40.
And I take it you were doing the testing of the camera in 39, is that right?
Oh, we started that about 38, I believe.
Okay.
I'm not quite sure.
That was about 38, the first camera.
Now, was your work really in seismic testing?
Was this leading to your master's thesis?
No.
I just never thought about thesis here.
Okay.
But I just didn't worry about such things as that.

I was interested in working on this program and we realized that when the time came that I was supposed to get a degree where then I would take some hunk of this large piece of work we were doing and call that my thesis and write it up on that basis.
Then a geology professor from the University of Virginia was a very good friend of Franklin Roosevelt's.
He talked Roosevelt into sponsoring a year's expedition in the South Pacific.
We were going to go in the Alexander Hamilton, one of the great 327-foot Coast Guard cutters.
Summer of 39, I guess it was, we all just worked like dogs getting ready for that because we were going to spend two months in each of the major island groups in the South Pacific.
That was canceled about three days before sailing time because of the war clouds.
It was probably unfortunate, because if we'd gone through with it, we would have probably learned a good deal more about the South Pacific before we moved into it.
I think in summing up some of the educational things, I was interested in geophysics and sort of problem-oriented.
Curricula was really one pretty much of classical physics, which I wasn't very much interested in, which was probably not very smart of me, but I was.
And I never really worried very much about whether I got a degree or not.
That was very secondary.
We had some very fine professors in the university.
And I think one of the things we learned, a great deal of versatility in getting things done.
There was very little money.
Partly you had to do it yourself.
Partly you designed according to what you could do.
The facilities that you had, the lathes or machine shops you had.
Incidentally, much of the work was done after midnight because
Only then could you break out your bogus master keys and so forth.

And I want to pay special tribute to the many service, wonderful service people in universities and so forth that help you along the mechanics, the policemen, and people like that who oftentimes make life far more livable.
For six months, I lived illegally in the laboratory.
slept on the floor in my research lab.
And many is the time the policeman would open up the gymnasium in the middle of the night so we could take showers after working.
And many is the night he came into my room and closed the windows if it was raining or snowing on me, even though I was engaged in illicit behavior.
Those are things one remembers a long time.
Ewing and Islin, of course, got to know each other in their respective work.
We were going out on the Atlantis.
And Islin was very involved in international matters and concerns.
after the war had broken out in Europe, it seemed inevitable that we were going to get into it.
And he put in a proposal to the National Research Council to get the oceanographic involved in the field of underwater sound and so forth.
He turned to Morris Ewing because Ewing was a contemporary who was experienced in seagoing work, experienced in geophysics and underwater sound.
In 1940, fall of 1940, I think it was October,

after we came back from a trip on the Atlantis down to Jacksonville, testing our, using our seismic and camera equipment, this contract appeared to go through, and Warzel, Ewing, and Bob McCurdy and I came from Lehigh up to Woods Hole to go to work on this.
Are you talking about a contract for anti-submarine warfare?
It was a contract for
anti-submarine, basically anti-submarine warfare work.
And this is in October 1940?
This is in October of 1940.
The first job, well at that moment I guess one could say the first job was that Ewing went up to talk to Islin and he telephoned back from Woods Hole and said the deal had gone through.
that could Wurzel and I clean out the laboratory and get up there in 48 hours.
So we hired a five-ton truck and took everything apart in 48 hours, of which about 12 hours, many hours, consisted of taking library books back to the library.
The primary job there at Woods Hole
And I might say a word about Woods Hole.
This was at the end of the summer.
The building was almost completely empty.
The Atlantis with her crew of 13 or 14 people was about.
There were about five other people in the oceanographic building, and we had it pretty much to ourselves.
The general understanding of sound transmission through the water was the primary problem we devoted ourselves to.
The theory of it, trying to get the, with principal emphasis on the bathymograph for shallow water and looking at historical records for deep water conditions.
We sort of divided the effort, but everybody worked on, rotated and almost everybody worked on every piece of it from time to time.
One of my principal concerns was to see if we could convert the bath thermograph from working at four knots to see if we could make it work at 15 knots and to go deeper and to make it more reliable.
and to build winches so it could do this also.
The other problem which Ewing spearheaded, but we all spent a great deal of time on it, was the refraction of sound in seawater.
And actually, from the first of October

to February, when the report was written of sound transmission in seawater, which was, I believe, an extremely fine and fundamental document, even to this day, as elementary as it was, why it was still a basically sound document.
Clearly building on other work that had been done by other people and so forth, but tying it together.
There is a certain amount of unfairness in many things.
The people at Scripps and at the Naval Electronics Laboratory in San Diego were working on the same problem.
I guess we beat them to the press by a very short length of time, and perhaps it was a little more
a little more complete, and certainly the report that Woods Hole put out, which was largely a result of Ewing and Islin combining physics and oceanography on a problem.
It was the teamwork of that group, and certainly my involvement was support rather than the major part of it.
That was a very monumental document at that time.
The point I want to make is that the people on the West Coast were doing very much of the same kind of work with a somewhat different tack.
And the work they did supported it, broadened the field, and so forth.
Well, during that war period, as the institution grew,
you took on all sorts of jobs.
And versatility was the game here.
Underwater sound was by all odds the principal part of it.
Excuse me, you stayed at Woods Hole then from 40 to 45 doing any submarine research?
Yes.
Okay.
Now, but you're in Operation Crossroad in 46?
Yes.
Right, okay.
Now, did Ewing stay between 40 and 45 here too?
Ewing was here all through then until he left in 46, spring of 46.
Spring of 46.
Yes.
What about Revell?
Ravel was at Scripps, and then he, working closely with the Naval Electronics Laboratory, it became the Naval Electronics Laboratory, also an underwater sound oceanography.
Then he got in the Navy as an officer, and he went to Washington.
And here I think the important thing is that Ravel was Mr. Oceanography in Washington.
There was no question about that.

one of the things in which the country as a whole was fortunate, and certainly as an individual I was very fortunate, to have this great triumvirate of smart, concerned scientists, Morris Ewing, Roger Revelle, and Columbus Isley.
Okay, now what all these questions are leading to is, what I really want to know is, when did you first meet Revelle?
I would say I probably met Revelle in about 42.
Okay.
Well, good.
Possibly earlier.
I'm not sure of this.
Is this through Granny's submarine work?
Yes.
Okay.
Well, I had met him before.
Yeah.
But just at meetings, and I didn't know him before.
Okay.
When I got to know Revelle was when you, you know, after working until 6 o'clock in the morning with...
all day long until 6 o'clock in the morning with people time after time, that's when you get to know them.
He told me he met you during the war in any submarine war.
Yes.
Okay.
And I wasn't trying to mislead you on the tape, but I somehow or another assumed that he had met you when he had come, when you guys had done it together.
So I placed you out at the Pacific for a while.
No.
Okay.
No, he was Mr. Oceanography there, and we had perhaps met then, but I didn't really get to know him until he got to Washington.
What sort of work were you doing in ASMRing warfare with acoustics?
What were you looking for?
The basic problem was, from the physics standpoint of it, the basic scientific point of view was to study the transmission of sound through the ocean.
That was the basic title of contracts that Ravel led to about three laboratories for about one decade or a decade and a half.
This was the simple statement that justified the expenditure of at least half of the money going into oceanography.
It was interpreted very broadly by all the people concerned.
And usually, if you take almost any broad problem, and in fundamental problem, interpret it broadly, and tackle it intelligently, that ends up by taking in about half of oceanography.
And this was the case.
I wanted to come back to this, saying that I believe the country as a whole was very lucky.

that Ewing, Revelle, and Islin were a trio of three wonderful people, talented people, that were fortunate enough to be able to stay together, I mean to operate, and they were, the three together, were really Mr. Oceanography for about 15 years.
They were all highly respected by military people, congressmen,
laymen, and so forth.
They were educated people, educated and concerned.
And it was this coherence in the business that was so very important.
In the field of oceanography during the war,
first with the elementary fundamental parts on the sound transmission, then getting the equipment.

We had classes of junior naval officers come to Woods Hole, and in one week we gave them a taste of what they were supposed to tell their superiors when they took the bath thermograph and put it out in the fleet.
Incidentally, we built about 250 bath thermographs here in Woods Hole in our shops.
waiting for production people to get them into production.
I was sort of Revell's manager for the bath thermographic equipment, commercial bath thermographic equipment and winches and so forth in commercial production.
So I spent about 20% of my time on that.
Bureau of Ordinance, long about this time, fairly early in the war, in fact, very early in the war, the Ordinance Department came to us with underwater photography.
For example, shortly after Pearl Harbor, we were accosted to see how practical was it to make a photographic mosaic every day of the bottom of the entrance to Pearl Harbor.
For
About one month, nearly all other projects around here were dropped while we worked on that project.

Some of the earliest underwater television, some of the early television was put in cases and put underwater, and we learned how to manipulate it and so forth in ways that were very crude and probably wouldn't have done the job very well.
it would have done it some.

Furthermore, when the Navy thought they had sunk a submarine, a German submarine along our coast, we ended up with the job of taking one of our ships out and having our people go out and see if they could photograph the wreck and determine what submarine it was.
Usually it was a collier sunk in the previous war.
But
That certainly produced a great deal of field work and an acquaintance with the problems of field work.
One of the interesting things about this, this was an era in which a great many young people came through and got acquainted with oceanography.
John Ewing, Rusty Tyree, a large number of young people who
were here for a while, then went off to war or other places in education and came back into the game later on.
Then I spent some time on submarines, both in the photographic game and the sound transmission game.
But then we got involved with the, when I say we, Woods Hole, Ewing, Islin, and so forth,
with building bath thermographs for submarines, because it was felt submarines needed a bath thermograph.
We designed up about four models.
Ewing and I were doing most of this work, because at that time, Warzel was more heavily involved in the photography.
We built about four models of bath thermographs, which were tested in Key West.
And one rather interesting part about that, I believe model number four was finally accepted by the Navy as being okay to put into production.
We received that word on a Thursday.
Also on Thursday, Ewing and I figured we knew how the thing really should be built.
And so we redesigned the submarine bathymograph.
We built models.
We tested the devil out of them all weekend.
And Monday morning, the manufacturers, the Bristol company, came around, sent by the Navy to put the instrument in production.
And we put the new untested model in production.
This sounds more horrible now than it did in those days, because in those days, there was a greater tendency to
do what you thought was right.
And the idea of operating by committee was still pretty remote.
But if I may knock on wood, we were very lucky on that, because that ended up being a best demographic to which, to my knowledge, only two of them ever quit on patrol.
There were, of course, some 40 submarines that never came back, but presumably only a few.
The bath thermograph for submarines was exceedingly important.
And I think it was exceedingly important to the history of oceanography.
I'm probably guilty of overstating this, and I put it into the history because I think it is important
item for historians to think about.
It was important because it was an instrument that was generally located within a few feet of the commanding officer when he was at his command stations.
It was an instrument that not only helped
excuse me, what the instrument did, it gave an indication of temperature versus depth.
It was on a little smoke three-by-five card.
It was generally within a few feet of the commanding officer.
If there was a temperature gradient, it indicated a customary thing of isothermal water, a temperature gradient, and then rolled isothermal water below.
It indicated that sound conditions above might be good.
If the submarine got below...
that then your chances of evasion would be much greater.
And there is no question about it.
Any instrument that helps a man survive is going to be an instrument that is respected.
An instrument that helps them make an attack is also going to be respected.

The submarine people clearly understood that the ocean was three-dimensional, and I believe it was this simpatico relationship between oceanographers and submarine people, with a bath thermograph being the device that did it more than anything else, meant that when the war was over, the

A large number of submarine people who were some of the Navy's best, not by any means their only best, but some of their best, were firm believers in the bath thermograph and pretty firm believers in oceanography.
Incidentally, I think that the best recommendation that the bath thermograph ever received, and it was certainly a tribute to oceanography,

The one captain said that when he had been executive officer and when they had made an attack off the island of Truk, which was in trade wind country with deep ice thermal water, they knew they would take a pasting because sound conditions were excellent and they stood a very good chance of getting sunk.
The submarine made their attack.
They dove, and as they passed about 100 feet,
the executive officer leaned over with his finger and put a false negative gradient on the bath thermograph because he figured that way the crew would see it and they would feel better.
And there was a man that understood both the bath thermograph and he understood his crew.
Along about the time that Ewing and Warzel
time we were all getting involved in sound channel work, the importance of the sound channel might exist.
I had started working with the submarine people, and it seemed to me that with the submarine bath demograph and the submarine people, Oceanography stood a chance to do some real good.
Here were some people that had an opportunity to use
oceanographic information in a way that destroyer people cannot, because the destroyer man cannot dive to take advantage of temperature gradients.
Therefore, I pretty much committed my time exclusively to the submarine bath thermograph for most of the rest of the war.
At this time, along about this

One of my regrets then was that I had to get out of the experimental acoustic business and working with Ewing and Islin on the sound channel work, which turned out to be so extremely important, although it did not turn out to be useful during the war.

A small group of us at Woods Hole, starting with Bill Chevelle, myself, and Bumpus, and Ewing some, under the general cognizance of Dr. Redfield, General Direction, we tried to ride each American submarine on it, and some foreigners on it, some foreign submarines on their

deep dives out of local test areas and so forth, to indoctrinate the crew about the bath thermograph, to talk to them about its use in underwater sound, about its use in diving, because we had been asked by the Navy to see if oceanographic information could be of help to them in diving through density gradients they found that had
provided serious density anomalies in the diving of submarines.
A difference of one part in a thousand in the density of water represents a difference of about two tons in the buoyancy of the submarine.
And normally a submarine has to pump when it goes deep, but in the summer, oftentimes it had to flood.
These could have serious implications in the operation of the submarine.
And when they all had noisy pumps, it made a tremendous amount of difference to the noise they made.
We visited a wide variety of places, mostly New London, Portsmouth, New Hampshire, Manitowoc, Wisconsin, Key West, a little bit in Panama, and Mare Island in California.

giving lectures to submarine groups, but writing the submarines, taking information that would relate to how much the submarines compressed, because the submarine hull compresses more than water does.
It took about a year's work to bring simple theory and observations and a line of rationale and a line of education and manuals so we could get this information across to submarine people.
I think most of this was pretty useful.
Many submarine people found it extremely useful.
Many found it was largely irrelevant.
Much of this, some of this depended upon their personality, but mostly depended upon the areas they were operating in and the particular situation jobs they had.
But submarine people were certainly very receptive.
I found nearly all aspects of working with submarine people were
very instructive and very worthwhile, and I had tremendous respect for them.
In 1944, I went out to Pearl Harbor as the first of the oceanographers to go out.
This was at the request of Ravel, although it was under his sponsorship, actually.
We'd tried to get out earlier, but he had
worked very hard in trying to get arrangements for us to go all the way to Australia, but this meant we got out to Pearl about two months later than we might have otherwise.
